statements.statement: Physician-patients often give unwarranted or unhelpful recommendations or advice regarding their own care.
Physician-patients often arrive in the late stages of their disease.
Physician-patients require less explanation than non-physician patients in the discussion of their diagnosis.
Physician-patients often like to get technical with discussions of treatment options.
Physician-patients have an educated opinion on their treatment options.
Physician-patients have more realistic expectations of their disease process.
Physician-patients seem to have more internal drive to recover.
Physician-patients have better participation in their own care.
Physician-patients more often exhibit hypochondriac tendencies.
Physician-patients often self-diagnose before coming in, and this annoys me.
Physician-patients are more likely to demonstrate anxiety or helplessness than other patients.
Physician-patients are more likely to exhibit anger or reactance against their condition than other patients.
Physician-patients have simpler cases of disease.
Physician-patients allow me to examine them more closely.
Physician-patients are more demanding than non-physician patients.
Consults or appointments with physician-patients take less time than with non-physician patients.
Physician-patients consume fewer resources than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients require fewer visits and less follow-up than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients are often more grateful and reasonable than the average patient.
Physician-patients skip routine screening with greater frequency than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients are more adherent with follow-up and preventative medicine.
Physician-patients are less likely to present with trivial cases of disease.
Physician-patients have a better sense of humor about their condition.
Physician-patients are more enjoyable to treat.
Physician-patients cope with their conditions better.
I feel more pressured when treating patients who are physicians.
Physician-patients are more honest and truthful with me than other patients.
Physician-patients are more likely to communicate with me outside of consultations.
Family of physician-patients are easier to work with, and have more faith in my recommendations.
I feel I heal faster, or recover quicker from illnesses than many of my patients.
Physicians treating me appear to use out-of-date evidence in my treatments.
When presenting as a patient to another physician, I feel pressured to be a "good" patient.
I wait longer in my disease course to present to my physician than the average patient.
I probably trouble my physicians less than their average patient.
I am afraid that the questions I ask as a physician-patient are sometimes poorly-received or come across as disrespectful.
